transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Conservation of an important population of the Critically Endangered Southern River Terrapin,..Batagur affinis, in Southern Cambodia

description.narrative: Conservation of an important population of critically endangered Southern River Terrapin, Batagur affineis, in Southern Cambodia. In partnership with Wildlife Conservation Society, this project will improve the global conservation status of Batagur affinis by reducing threats to, and improving recruitment in an important remnant population in Cambodia. Specific activities include: (1) expand and increase effectiveness of patrols aimed at discovering additional nests using the SMART (Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool) method originally developed by WCS and USFWS for tiger conservation; (2) conduct in situ nest incubation and protection for all nests found in the wild that will be guarded by wardens; (3) transfer hatchling turtles from field incubation studies to head-starting facilities; (4) select and release 25 head-started turtles with an acoustic tag; (5) monitor turtles post release using an omni directional hydrophone and underwater automated recording stations.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to: 1) Protect elephants and resolve conflict situations, providing ranger protection to any conflict animals and guidance to local villagers; 2) Provide on-the-job training to rangers to improve anti-poaching patrols; 3) Provide wildlife law enforcement. Seize snares, traps, guns, vehicles and chainsaws. Bring perpetrators to court; 4) Increase number of cases prosecuted in court; 5) Maintain signs and demarcation posts which delineate community land and State forest to show people exactly where boundaries are located; 6) Monitor elephant habitat through daily patrols to avoid forest fires and stop encroachment on forestland.

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to: 1) Continue delivery of education curriculum to rural schools in the Cardamom Mountains and expand this outreach into national schools in Kompong Som and Phnom Penh, focusing on threats to Cambodias flagship species; 2) Continue capacity and understanding of key environmental issues among teachers, community educators, and community leaders through training, staff development, monitoring and evaluation, and provide multiple-use long lasting educational materials; 3) Complement environmental education awareness of both rural students and community members to reinforce lessons from the classroom through an anticipated 20 field trips to Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center for students and community members from around the country; 4) Continue building environmental awareness and pride in Cambodias natural heritage among students and communities through interactive hands-on Community Night Shows, which complement our work in schools. A minimum of 15 Community Night Shows will be conducted in the coming project year in Koh Kong and beyond; 5) Raise community awareness among Cambodians on a nationwide level regarding the devastating effects of the illegal wildlife trade, destruction of habitats, and other factors threatening Cambodias wildlife through large-scale signage and outreach activities via collaboration and engagement with national ministries, NGOs, and other institutions; 6) Complement conservation awareness-raising and large signage outreach efforts by installing matching signs and hotline stickers on 10 tuk-tuks in Phnom Penh for one year, publicizing the illegality of trading wildlife and promoting Wildlife Alliances 24-hour nationwide wildlife crime hotline.

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure the protection of the most important gibbon sites in this landscape. This will be done by: 1) training law enforcement staff from across the Northern Plains landscape and supplying them with basic equipment; 2) training patrol staff and community monitoring rangers in SMART monitoring techniques and implementation of SMART monitoring; 3) targeting patrols to reduce threats to pileated gibbons and their habitats; 4) improving liaison with provincial and national government to improve institutional support for conservation of gibbon habitat; and 5) undertaking consultations regarding the proposed zonation of Kulen Promtep Wildlife Sanctuary and preparing the draft maps for Ministerial discussion.

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue a focused enforcement program combined with law enforcement monitoring using state of the art tools to secure the long term conservation of the worlds largest known population of yellow-cheeked crested gibbons. This will be done by: (1) continuing operation of six ranger teams assigned one each to six ranger stations throughout the Protected Forest plus one additional mobile intervention squad based out of the Keo Seima base camp; (2) monitoring changes in forest cover and land use change through visual comparison of recent Landsat 7 imagery; and (3) improving the capacity of protection staff to implement law enforcement through presentation of two back to back 10-day training courses each involving two Forestry Administration patrol leaders and 12 law enforcement team members.

title.narrative: Cambodian Crocodile Conservation Programme: Ensuring the future of the critically endangered Siamese crocodile in the wild

description.narrative: Cambodian Crocodile Conservation Programme: Ensuring the Future of the Critically Endangered Siamese Crocodile in the Wild. In partnership with Fauna & Flora International this project will increase the viability of Siamese crocodiles in the wild through direct protection, in situ conservation, and captive breeding and reintroduction. Specific activities include: (1) conduct annual transect-based monitoring of crocodile abundance and reproduction at key sites; (2) conduct post-release monitoring of reintroduced crocodiles; (3) strengthen management and monitoring by having community wardens patrol three crocodile wetlands and one reintroduction site on a monthly basis and will report illegal activities to the authorities; (4) develop boundaries, regulations and management plans for the newly established crocodile sanctuaries with relevant stakeholders; (5) provide livelihoods and other social support enabling communities near key sites to reduce impacts on crocodiles and their habitat; (6) release at least 25 additional Siamese crocodiles from the Phnom Tamao Breeding Facility and the Areng Sanctuary into the six preselected sites; (7) test crocodile DNA test to identify purebred individuals that could potentially be released back into the wild; (8) facilitate crocodile conservation network meetings on a quarterly basis; (9) disseminate information on the conservation and cultural importance of the Siamese crocodiles to the Crocodile Conservation Network members as well as a wider audience.

title.narrative: Developing a standardized monitoring and protection system to conserve Asian elephant within the core landscape of the southern/eastern Cardamon mountains, Cambodia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to identify Asian elephant hotspots within the south-eastern Cardamom Mountains Landscape to inform future monitoring programs and management response, and support communities to mitigate human-elephant conflict (HEC). Grantee will, 1) Conduct fecal concentration surveys within the eastern and southern Cardamom Mountains Landscape to identify elephant hotspots, by end 2014; 2) Reduce human-elephant conflict through strengthening local management of human-elephant conflict at key sites.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to decrease the illegal trade of tiger and rhino horn specimens throughout the Mekong region of Southeast Asia. This will be done by: (1) increasing information sharing between the governments of Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, Lao PDR and China with regards to rhino horn and tiger trade routes, suspect profiles, and specific smuggling methods at specific border.crossings; and (2) improving performance of Thai, Vietnamese, Cambodian, Lao PDR and Chinese law enforcement officers in identifying and arresting high-level tiger and rhino horn traffickers...Specifically this will be done by: (1) facilitating bilateral and multilateral Special Investigation Group meetings that enable information sharing, joint training and planning among key rhino and tiger source, transit and consumer countries in the Mekong region; (2) training and equipping investigators to pursue cases and develop regional enforcement capacity; (3) providing on-the-ground training, mentoring and tip-off support, where requested, to government investigators (only in Thailand, not in Vietnam, China, Cambodia or Lao PDR); and (4) following major cases until their successful conclusion.."

title.narrative: Development of a marine turtle conservation program in Cambodia and piloting bycatch reduction on key foraging grounds

description.narrative: The recipient will; 1. work with the Cambodian Fisheries Administration to develop a National Marine Turtle Conservation Action Plan through stakeholder meetings and workshops and collection of technical and scientific data and; 2. develop and implement in coordination with Cambodian Fisheries Administration and Community fisheries organizations a pilot bycatch reduction project on important sea turtle foraging grounds within the Koh Rong Archipelago.

title.narrative: Cambodian Crocodile Conservation Programme: Ensuring the future of the critically endangered Siamese crocodile in the wild

description.narrative: This project will attempt to double the wild population of Siamese crocodiles by 2017 and to leverage the species as a flagship for conserving threatened rivers and wetlands in Cambodia. Specific activities include: (1) enhancing the viability of wild populations through restocking at least one additional wetland under the National Crocodile Re-Introduction and Reinforcement Strategy and Action Plan by 2015; (2) strengthening community management of crocodile sanctuaries established under precious CEACF support, and developing management plans for at least two new sanctuaries; (3) increasing awareness so that at least 10% of Cambodians are aware that the Siamese crocodile is indigenous, rare, and protected by law, to be accomplished through surveys of the public, an enhanced education program at Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Centre aimed at reaching 50,000 people per year, and frequent features on crocodiles and this project in various forms of media; (4) monitoring the crocodile population and disseminating project methods, results, and impacts to benefit further conservation planning in Cambodia and throughout the species range.

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to deliver an education curriculum that includes information regarding wildlife and forestry laws and information that will enable Cambodians to make informed decisions regarding the sustainable management of their natural resources while promoting protection of areas rich in biodiversity. This will be done by: 1) delivering a gibbon-focused environmental curriculum to students (3,000), teachers (200), community members, and community leaders in Koh Kong, Kompong Som, and Phnom Penh; 2) conducting at least 15 conservation oriented Community Night Shows and 20 field trips to Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center (PTWRC); 3) conducting follow up visits to each school to ensure that teachers are delivering the environmental education lessons and to provide them continuing support in doing that; 6) expanding the Kouprey Express partnership network to provinces not previously addressed; and 7) renewing existing signs and installing new, high visibility multi-lingual billboards and double-sided overhead signs at highly trafficked intersections having conservation messages targeting illegal trafficking of wildlife.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Enhanced conservation of Yellow-cheeked Crested Gibbon (Nomascus gabriellae) through.direct protection and ecotourism in southern Mondulkiri, Cambodia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure the long-term conservation of the largest population of Yellow-cheeked Crested Gibbon in the world through effective protection of the core area of Seima Protection Forest and the development gibbon-based ecotourism. This will be done by: 1) direct protection of gibbons and their habitat; 2) monitoring of law enforcement efforts using SMART conservation software; 3) developing a community-based ecotourism project that will allow visitors to see gibbons in their natural habitat; and 4) monitoring key indicators of the ecotourism project including the gibbons and their ecology, habitat use, movement patterns, and the impacts of the project on the local community.

title.narrative: Establishing gibbon monitoring in Bokor National Park through supporting Cambodias future..conservation professionals

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to initiate a pileated gibbon monitoring program by conducting repeat surveys at 10 sites in Bokur NP. This will be done by: 1) developing a pileated gibbon monitoring protocol for Bokor NP; 2) identifying areas of high gibbon density within Bokor NP and their preferred habitat; 3) determining the feasibility of undertaking a joint approach to long term gibbon monitoring and conservation in the park with the parks major concession holder Thansur Bokor Mountain Resort and the national parks management; and 4) improving national capacity to undertake gibbon conservation.

title.narrative: Measuring Asian elephant abundance and mitigating human-elephant conflict in the core landscape of the southern/eastern Cardamom Mountains, Cambodia

description.narrative: This purpose of this project is to estimate the population size of Asian elephants within the southeastern Cardamom Mountains Landscape to better understand population trends and inform future monitoring programs and management responses and support communities in mitigating human-elephant conflict (HEC.) Project activities will include: 1) estimation of the elephant population through capture-mark-recapture analysis of DNA extracted from dung samples collected from hotspots; 2) reduction of HEC through supporting and equipping government-led HEC response teams and providing training to four local guarding groups; 3) support maintenance and function of three non-formal primary schools by providing teacher salaries, teaching materials, and school supplies; and 4) install a series of HEC-mitigating beehive fences in a local community and provide training on sustainable bee husbandry. This project will contribute to the stabilization and increase in the population of wild Asian elephants in Cambodia.

title.narrative: Strengthening control of ivory trafficking in Cambodia: Implementing the National Ivory Action Plan

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Forestry Administration to implement the activities specified in the government-endorsed National Ivory Action Plan (NIAP) in its first year of implementation. Project activities will include: 1) revise the Government proclamation No. 020 PR. MAFF on Classification and List of Wildlife Species to include African elephants on the list of Endangered Species; 2) develop regulatory and internal procedures for establishing, registering, and managing seized ivory; 3) coordinate a workshop for prosecutors, judiciary, and relevant law enforcement agencies to increase awareness and prosecutions of wildlife crime; and 4) support local bilateral meetings between Vietnam and Cambodia to improve trans-boundary cooperation related to wildlife trafficking and wildlife crime investigation and enforcement. Implementation of the NIAP will strengthen the control of ivory trafficking through Cambodia, and by reducing poaching pressure on Asian elephants while increasing anti-trafficking efforts, this project will reduce overall demand for ivory from both Asian and African elephants.

title.narrative: Elephant conservation & capacity building in Seima Protection Forest, Cambodia - Year 8

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to sustain and improve conservation of Asian elephants and build capacity of rangers and community patrols in Seima Protection Forest. Project activities will include: 1) implement anti-poaching patrols and monitoring of elephant habitat; 2) monitor forest loss and encroachment using remote sensing and Geographic Information Systems; 3) establish community patrol teams in one new village; 4) increase capacity of new and existing community patrols through training and equipment; 5) establish a reporting network for human-elephant conflict; 6) conduct extensive training for field teams on survey methods and protocols; and 7) conduct the HEC survey in parallel with the elephant DNA survey. This project will contribute to a well-managed forest landscape that supports increasing wildlife populations and improved livelihoods for the communities of the Seima Protection Forest.

title.narrative: ROOST PROTECTION AND HABITAT CREATION FOR THE WHITE-SHOULDERED IBIS IN NORTHERN CAMBODIA

description.narrative: This project will promote a stable or increasing population of White-shouldered Ibis in Western Siem Pang Forest and Lomphat Wildlife Sanctuary. The grantee will undertake an innovative method to create additional habitat; specific objectives include: (1) Playback of bird calls; (2) The use of dolly (model) birds to encourage live birds to join new communal roosting sites; (3) The enhancement of preferred White-shouldered Ibis foraging habitat by the digging of forest pools trapeangs as key foraging resources for the species.

title.narrative: Direct protection to Asia's last intact elephant corridor, Cambodia

description.narrative: The Southern Cardamom Forest Protection Program (SCFPP) implements a direct, holistic approach to forest protection in Cambodia, providing ranger patrols which protect wild Asian elephants and their habitats from poaching and land encroachment in this landscape. This project will protect Asian elephants by improving ranger effectiveness through training, strengthen good governance by building strong cases and following-up with the courts on active cases; provide investigative skill development training; and create better linkages between remote villages and ranger stations to address land encroachment. SCFPP rangers will conduct daily forest patrols to effectively resolve human-elephant conflicts, operate ranger stations, and preserve the forests of the Southern Cardamom Mountains of Cambodia.

title.narrative: Pileated Gibbon Conservation Education and Public Outreach through the Kouprey Express

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to deliver an education curriculum that includes information regarding wildlife and forestry laws and information, enabling Cambodians to make informed decisions about the sustainable management of their natural resources while promoting protection of areas rich in biodiversity. The project objectives include the following: (1) Deliver an education curriculum to national schools in the Cardamom Mountains, and Kompong Som and Phnom Penh, focusing on threats to Cambodias gibbons and other flagship species, (2) Build capacity and understanding of key environmental issues among teachers, community educators, and community leaders in communities, schools and NGOs in target areas as well as other provinces through training, staff development, monitoring, (3) Conduct an anticipated 20 field trips to Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center to complement classroom lessons and environmental education awareness outreach activities for students and community members from around the country and evaluation, (4) Build environmental awareness and pride in Cambodias natural heritage among students and communities through interactive hands-on Community Night Shows, which complement the work in schools, (5) Conduct wildlife ID and anti-smuggling training and follow up seminars with Customs and Excise officers, freight forwarders, cargo handlers, border police, and other relevant personnel at the main points of entry and transit, including but not limited to Phnom Penh and Siem Reap International Airports, the Autonomous Port of Sihanoukville, Phnom Penh Dry Port, and other relevant agencies, (6) Raise community awareness among Cambodians on a nationwide level regarding the devastating effects of illegal wildlife trade through large-scale signage and outreach activities via collaboration and engagement with national ministries, NGOs, and other institutions, and (7) Complement conservation awareness-raising and large signage outreach efforts by installing

title.narrative: Northern Plains of Cambodia Pileated Gibbon Conservation Project: Phase 6

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to conserve the pileated gibbon population in the Northern Plains of Cambodia by strengthening existing law enforcement monitoring strategies, establishing new integrated community led patrolling approaches and implementing innovative patrol reporting systems. The following objectives and associated activities will be accomplished: (1) Ensure effective protection of pileated gibbons and their habitats by targeted patrol planning and implementation of automated patrol reporting systems, by (a) training patrol staff to implement and instruct communities in the use of an automated SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrol reporting system, and (b) conducting targeted SMART patrols to reduce threats to pileated gibbons and priority habitat areas; (2) Improve community liaisons between patrol team staff and village level institutions, by (a) conducting community workshops titled The Importance of Priority Gibbon Habitat in the Northern Plains (at village, commune and district levels), improving awareness and community support for priority habitats, and (b) electing community patrol team members from key villages and providing training for these teams to conduct SMART patrols.

title.narrative: Long-term conservation of Yellow-cheeked crested gibbon through direct law enforcement and community engagement in southern Mondulkiri, Cambodia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to have well-managed forest landscape that supports increasing wildlife populations, especially gibbons, and improving livelihoods for the people who currently live there. The following objectives and associated activities will be accomplished: (1) Protect gibbons by maintaining extensive law enforcement activities, by (a) continuing proactive law enforcement activities to protect sensitive gibbon habitat, and (b) refining the use of remote sensing and the SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) software to inform adaptive management; (2) Expand and strengthen community engagement in, and support of, gibbon conservation, by (a) continued capacity building for tourism development and improved community engagement, and (b) further refinement and implementation of robust monitoring of the gibbon populations in the ecotourism area.

title.narrative: Enhanced Protection and Habitat Conservation for At-Risk Ape Populations in Cambodia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to establish a long-term protection mechanism and serve as a model for enhancing protection of critical wildlife sites in NE India where situations are dire and manpower is short. The project will accomplish the following objectives and associated activities: (1) Continue the operations of the two roving gibbon and wildlife patrol units comprising of 3 community members and headed by a forest guard. A new group will also be introduced this year resulting in a total of 3 groups. (2) Implement SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrolling protocols; systematically record patrol details and produce monthly reports; plan future patrols using these reports. FWS support will provide the salaries of 8 guards and honorariums for 3 forest staff for 12 months. There will be special training of the guards on wildlife conservation, how to combat poaching, and SMART patrolling.

title.narrative: Combating wildlife trafficking in Cambodia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to scale up the successful results of the Wildlife Rapid Rescue Team (WRRT) in Cambodia to address pan-Asian wildlife trafficking and support the Cambodian Government to achieve its 2016-2017 goal of instutionalizing a National Wildlife Crime Program. This project is intended to conserve many protected and unprotected species, including Asian elephants, Indochinese tigers, clouded leopards, Malyan sunbears, slow loris, pileated Gibbons and pangolins, as well as African elephants and rhinos. Specific activities include: (1) training 40 officers involved in wildlife law enforcement on surveillance, wildlife identification, investigation techniques, preparation of prosecution documents and wildlife care and handling; (2) conducting joint operations with these officers to provide practice experience and guidance on lessons learned during the training sessions; and (3) improving existing partnerships with counterparts on the borders of Thailand, Laos, and Vietnam to promote corss border investigations and prosecutions.

title.narrative: Asian elephant conservation education through the Kouprey Express, Cambodia.

description.narrative: ?The purpose of this project is to continue to fund the only environmental education team in Cambodia, and brings the plight of the Asian elephant and ivory trade to the Cambodian public. The project has expanded its reach and scope via a MoU with the Government of Cambodia to include national schools and communities in Phnom Penh and Preah Sihanouk, home to Cambodias largest port. The Kouprey Express Environmental Education Program (KE) consists of a curriculum that builds the capacities of students and teachers through a national awareness campaign that highlights poaching, wildlife trade, habitat loss and habitat degradation and fragmentation. A strong anti-ivory message aims to reduce local and regional demand and complicity in the transport of ivory into, through, and out of Cambodia. Specific project activities will include: 1) delivery of education curriculum to rural schools in the Cardamom Mountains, Kompong Som and Phnom Penh, focusing on threats to flagship species; 2) improving the understanding of key environmental issues among teachers, community educators, and leaders through training, staff development, monitoring and evaluation, and provide multiple-use long lasting educational materials; 3) conduct field trips to Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center for students and community members; 4) conducting 15+ interactive hands-on Community Night Shows; 5) conduct anti-ivory and wildlife ID trainings with Customs and Excise officers at primary points of entry; 6) raise awareness on the devastating effects of the illegal wildlife trade with a focus on elephants and ivory through community outreach programs, installation of billboards, and posting hotline stickers on 10 tuk-tuks in Phnom Penh, promoting Wildlife Alliances 24-hour nationwide wildlife crime hotline. This projects on-the-ground elephant protection and anti-ivory campaign and education and community outreach program combined with the recipients on-going work in wildlife crime law enfor

title.narrative: Reducing Threats to Elephants and Mitigating Human-Elephant Conflict in the Core Habitat of the Cardamom Mountain Landscape, Cambodia

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to reduce threats to wild Asian elephant conservation and population recovery in the Cardamom Mountain Landscape of Cambodia and support communities in mitigating human-elephant conflict (HEC). Specific projects objectives are: 1) reduce demand for wildlife products; 2) support the government in zoning and demarcation of key elephant habitats; and 3) reduce HEC through sustainable mitigation techniques and local management of HEC at key sites. Project activities include: 1) develop a wildlife products demand reduction campaign; 2) work with government authorities to zone protected areas with a special focus on key elephant habitat and connectivity; 3) support government-led HEC response teams to educate and train local stakeholders in conflict mitigation; 4) support two primary schools within elephant habitat to enable local school children to receive an education and build community support for conservation activities; and 5) investigate and pilot innovative and sustainable methods for HEC mitigation and reduction. This project will contribute to the stabilization and long-term growth of the Asian elephant population in Cambodia.

title.narrative: Direct Protection to Asias Last Intact Elephant Corridor.

description.narrative: This project endeavors to protect wild Asian elephants in the Southern Cardamom Mountains of Cambodia from poaching, prevent forest fragmentation and encroachment, and preserve continuous forest cover for elephant movement. Project activities include: 1) conduct capacity building and professionalization training for forest rangers in order for increase their effectiveness in cases involving high-ranking officials and middlemen involved in wildlife trafficking; 2) provide legal support in court proceedings, legal documentation procedures, and ensure cases are prosecuted; 3) increase effectiveness of intelligence gathering to obtain information leading to wildlife smuggling rings and logging syndicates; and 4) create better linkages between remote villages and ranger stations to address land encroachment in the elephant corridor. Through forest and wildlife protection via ranger law enforcement and forest protection this project will contribute to the conservation and survival of wild Asian elephants in Cambodia.

title.narrative: Elephant conservation and capacity-building in Keo Seima Wildlife Sanctuary, Cambodia: Year 9

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to improve the protection and conservation status of Asian elephants in Keo Seima Wildlife Sanctuary, Cambodia. The main objectives of this project are to improve anti-snare capacity through applied research and a collection incentive scheme; protect elephants and habitat through targeted law enforcement and anti-snare patrols; and reduce human-elephant conflict (HEC) through implementation of a community-funded insurance scheme. Project activities include: 1) conduct anti-snare efficacy research to identify maximum return-on-investment strategies; 2) improve and re-implement snare collection incentives for anti-snare teams; 3) use remote sensing to detect forest loss and encroachment into high-priority elephant areas and inform patrol planning; 4) conduct law enforcement patrols in high priority areas; 5) review, compile, and collect data to inform design of insurance scheme; 6) conduct feasibility assessment of community-funded insurance scheme in Andong Kralong village; and 7) build capacity of Andong Kralong community to implement insurance scheme.

title.narrative: Strengthening control of ivory trafficking in Cambodia; implementing the NIAP, Phase 2.

description.narrative: This project builds upon the work undertaken in USFWS award #F15AP00349 , to provide strategic capacity building and technical support to key law enforcement agencies at international trafficking points, to combat trafficking of wildlife, in particular of elephant ivory and rhino horn with the ultimate goal of reducing the trafficking of elephant ivory and rhino horn through Cambodia. Project activities include: 1) conduct training for key law enforcement agencies to intercept and prosecute wildlife trafficking cases at key points in Cambodia; 2) provide technical support to the sampling and inventory of ivory and rhino horns that are seized by law enforcement agencies; 3) establish a secure repository for confiscated wildlife products; and 4) provide technical advice to the national CITES Management Authority. This project will contribute to the strengthening of capacity and awareness within primary law enforcement agencies to combat wildlife trafficking in Cambodia.

title.narrative: Understanding Peoples Attitudes and Behavior Towards Wildlife: Designing a Theory of Change for the Demand Reduction of Bear Products in Cambodia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter wildlife trafficking in Southeast Asia, specifically in Cambodia, by developing a Theory of Change to reduce demand for bear parts. This project is intended to conserve vulnerable bear species, including the Asiatic black bear (Ursus thibetanus) and the sun bear (Helarctos malayanus), by addressing the impacts of increased poaching pressure for meat/parts, traditional Chinese medicine, and other products. Specific activities will include: (1) conducting surveys and focus groups with Cambodian residents on their attitudes towards and behaviors regarding bear parts use; (2) leading human-centered design and social marketing tools to design and test behavior change tools across different social and geographical contexts; (3) presenting final behavior change strategy and tools through interactive workshops at each study site; and (4) training and knowledge transfer to Cambodian partners such as Free The Bears and the Royal University of Phnom Penh.

title.narrative: Reducing Trafficking of Cambodia's Cantor's Giant Softshelled Turtle

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter endangered turtle trafficking in Kratie and Stung Treng provinces, Cambodia, by building upon a currently successful model of community and local government engagement. This project is intended to conserve the endangered Cantors Giant Softshelled Turtle, pelochelys cantorii, by addressing the impacts of local consumption and international trade of the turtles and their eggs. Specific activities will include: (1) engage community members with high community standing as Turtle Ambassadors to participate in adult/fisher education sessions and patrols in current target sites; (2) extending the efforts of current Community Rangers; (3) extending and expanding our community education program in current target sites; and (4) rollout of project activities in a newly identified hunting hotspot.

title.narrative: Improved Protection from Illegal Trade, Including Population Expansion for Endangered Ape Species in Cambodia

description.narrative: This an ongoing project to coordinate law enforcement efforts against the illegal wildlife trade and reintroduce captive gibbons back to the wild in an area from which they have been extirpated. Cambodia is a source, transit, and destination country for the illegal wildlife trade, leaving gibbons and other endangered species in rapid decline. Wildlife Alliance has been fighting the illegal wildlife trade in Southeast Asia since 2001 by supporting the Wildlife Rapid Rescue Team (WRRT), the only full-time counter-trafficking unit in the region dedicated to combatting the illegal wildlife trade. Increased demand and decreased supply, combined with WRRT success, has led to the creation of better resourced, more sophisticated wildlife traders. The project has the following objectives: (1) Increased capacity of WRRT to conduct effective and efficient investigations and operations through improved investigative techniques, increased training of provincial officers, ensuring good governance monitoring legal procedures and court cases; and, (2) Increased recognition of the importance and viability of rehabilitation and release as a tool in the conservation of apes.

title.narrative: Pileated Gibbon Conservation Education and Public Outreach in Cambodia and Eastern Thailand through the Kouprey Express

description.narrative: oject will help the Kouprey Express build upon its successes and continue to strengthen public awareness and support for the protection of the endangered pileated gibbon, Asian elephant, other endangered wildlife, in both Cambodia and Thailand. This project will: (1) Empower youth and communities to make informed decisions regarding the sustainable management of their natural resources; (2) Engage rural communities in wildlife protection and raise community awareness among rural Cambodians regarding the devastating effects of the illegal wildlife trade; (3) Increase awareness about Cambodias wildlife laws and Wildlife Alliances nationwide wildlife rescue hotline number via on-the-ground public outreach, signage, and public service announcements; (4) Increase awareness about wildlife trafficking, methods of smuggling, and species identification through specialized training for Customs officers, cargo and freight handlers, and other relevant personnel at ports and airports; (5) Build capacities and support grassroots efforts of teachers and youth to create and implement their own wildlife protection lessons and activities; and, (6) Promote a conservation ethic in Cambodia.

title.narrative: Direct protection to Asia's Last Intact Elephant Corridor, Cambodia

description.narrative: The Southern Cardamom Forest Protection Program (SCFPP) implements a direct, holistic approach to forest protection in Cambodia, providing ranger patrols which protect wild Asian elephants and their habitats from poaching and land encroachment in this landscape. The goal of this ongoing project is to achieve zero elephant poaching events, prevent forest fragmentation, and preserve continuous forest cover for elephant movement. This project will protect Asian elephants by improving ranger effectiveness through training, strengthen good governance by building strong cases and following-up with the courts on active cases; provide investigative skill development training; and create better linkages between remote villages and ranger stations to address land encroachment. SCFPP rangers will conduct daily forest patrols to effectively resolve human-elephant conflicts, operate ranger stations, and preserve the forests of the Southern Cardamom Mountains of Cambodia.

title.narrative: Elephant conservation in Keo Seima Wildlife Sanctuary, Cambodia: Phase 10, Years 1-3

description.narrative: The goal of this three-year project is the ongoing protection and enhancement of the conservation status of wild Asian elephants in Keo Seima Wildlife Sanctuary (KSWS), Cambodia. KSWS is a globally important site for biodiversity conservation located in the Eastern Plains Landscape of Cambodia, the area boasts a complex mix of forest types as well as elevation gradients, which leads to a high species richness across a range of taxa. The main objectives of this project are to improve anti-snare capacity through applied research and a collection incentive scheme; protect elephants and habitat through targeted law enforcement and anti-snare patrols; and protect elephants and their habitat from illegal forest encroachment. Project activities include: 1) conduct anti-snare patrols to reduce snare abundance in key elephant areas; 2) collect snare abundance data to improve the efficiency of anti-snare patrols; 3) evaluate the effectiveness of pilot snare collection incentives; 4) use remote sensing to target law enforcement patrols within key areas for elephants; and 5) conduct law enforcement patrols in high-priority elephant areas at the deforestation frontier.

title.narrative: Reducing Threats to Elephants and Mitigating Human-Elephant Conflict in the Core Habitat of the Cardamom Mountain Landscape, Cambodia

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to reduce threats to wild Asian elephants and population recovery in the Cardamom Mountain Landscape of Cambodia and support communities in mitigating human-elephant conflict (HEC). Specific projects objectives are: 1) prevent potentially fatal snare injuries to elephants by reducing the commercial demand for bushmeat in urban areas through a research-led behavior change campaign, and contribute to a reduction in incentives to set snares in elephant habitat; 2) support community wardens to monitor elephants, threats, and HEC; and 3) reduce HEC through sustainable mitigation techniques and local management of HEC at key sites. Activities include: 1) support an effective nationwide demand reduction campaign targeting bushmeat consumption; 2) support community elephant wardens to use camera traps and Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) to monitor elephant presence, threats, and HEC; 3) educate and train local stakeholders in HEC mitigation; 4) establish new government-led HEC response teams; 5) reduce HEC in impacted communities by developing and testing mitigation techniques; and 6) build community support for conservation activities through support to targeted primary schools. This project will contribute to the stabilization and long-term increase of the Asian elephant population in Cambodia.

title.narrative: Continuing Pileated Gibbon Conservation Education and Public Outreach in Cambodia through the Kouprey Express

description.narrative: The project will accomplish the following objectives: (1) Continue building capacity and understanding of key environmental issues for 300 teachers, community educators, and community leaders in communities, schools and NGOs in target areas as well as all other provinces through training, staff development, monitoring and evaluation; (2) Bring a gibbon-focused education curriculum to an estimated 7,500 students at national schools and NGOs around the country and in the Cardamom Mountains; (3) Conduct an anticipated 20 field trips to Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center to complement classroom lessons and environmental education awareness outreach activities for students and community members from around the country; (4) Build environmental awareness and pride in Cambodias natural heritage among students and communities through interactive hands-on Community Night Shows, which complement our work in schools; (5) Continue collaboration with other conservation NGOs on capacity building to help facilitate their own environmental education teams as a means of ensuring our message continues; (6) Continue to conduct Wildlife ID and anti-smuggling training with new Customs and Excise officers from Phnom Penh and Siem Reap International Airports and other relevant agencies; and, (7) Raise community awareness among Cambodians on a nationwide level regarding the devastating effects of the illegal wildlife trade with a focus on gibbons, destruction of habitats, and other factors threatening Cambodias wildlife through large-scale signage and outreach activities in collaboration with others.

title.narrative: Strengthening marine turtle conservation and critical habitat protection in Cambodia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue support for development of a marine turtle conservation program for Cambodia. This project ddresses threats to nesting beach development, nest poaching and fisheries bycatch of marine turtles. Activities include: (1) in collaboration with Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Administration continue implementation of the National Conservation Action Plan developed in 2015 with MTCA support; (2) conduct nesting surveys to assess status of nesting at historically known nesting sites; (3) continue a gear replacement/sea turtle bycatch reduction project with small scale fisheries organizations; (4) conduct safe handling and release training workshops with fisheries in high threat interaction zones; (5) organize community fishery patrols to reduce and deter illegal fishing in areas of known high sea turtle bycatch; (6) conduct education and outreach activities in select coastal communities where sea turtle/human interactions are greatest; and (7) organize and conduct a regional capacity building and data sharing workshop in Cambodia with Myanmar, Thailand, Vietnam.

title.narrative: REDUCING CONSUMER DEMAND FOR IVORY IN CAMBODIA THROUGH STRENGTHENED CAPACITY, WILDLIFE LAW ENFORCEMENT, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT

description.narrative: This project will support the Kouprey Express and the Wildlife Rapid Rescue Team (WRRT) to reduce threats to Asian elephants and demand for ivory in Cambodia through an approach that encompasses both wildlife law enforcement and demand reduction. The Kouprey Express Environmental Education Program empowers youth and communities to make responsible decisions regarding the sustainable management of natural resources; effect positive change; shifts in attitudes, behaviors, and actions towards wildlife and their habitat; promote pride and grassroots action to protect Asian elephants and other wildlife; and reduce consumption of ivory. The WRRT has an essential role in combating wildlife crime in Cambodia and is responsible for the majority of wildlife crime investigations in the country. This project will address threats to Asian elephants by: (1) directly combating the illegal trade in ivory through focused investigations; (2) increasing governmental and institutional capacity; (3) empowering youth and communities to make responsible decisions and shifts in attitudes, behaviors, and actions regarding the sustainable management of Cambodias wildlife and natural resources; and (4) promote pride and grassroots action to protect Asian elephants by reducing consumption for ivory. Project activities include: (1) build capacities of 750+ teachers and community leaders through three-day workshops on core environmental concepts; (2) reach 10,500+ Cambodian youth through hands-on environmental education and elephant conservation lessons, field trips to Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center, and school visits; (3) conduct door-to-door outreach and 15+ Community Night Shows in rural communities to share information about elephants, wildlife laws, and human-elephant conflict (HEC); (4) broadcast two animated public service announcements on television to promote the wildlife rescue hotline and demand reduction messages; (5) use a targeted social media campaign in Khmer, English, and

title.narrative: DRIVING PRIORITY CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR ASIAN ELEPHANTS IN THE EASTERN PLAINS LANDSCAPE OF CAMBODIA

description.narrative: THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE KNOWLEDGE BASE AND CAPACITY OF AUTHORITIES AND COMMUNITIES TO TRACK ELEPHANT MOVEMENTS AND POPULATION TRENDS AND REDUCE HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC) IN THE EASTERN PLAINS LANDSCAPE (EPL) OF CAMBODIA. PHNOM PRICH WILDLIFE SANCTUARY (PPWS) AND SREPOK WILDLIFE SANCTUARY (SWS), TWO ADJACENT PROTECTED AREAS INSIDE THE EPL, ARE CONTIGUOUS WITH YOK DON NATIONAL PARK (YDNP) IN VIET NAM AND HOME TO 500 ASIAN ELEPHANTS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO: (1) CONDUCT ELEPHANT COLLARING IN EPL (2) CONDUCT FECAL DNA ASSESSMENTS TO MEASURE ELEPHANT POPULATION SIZE AND VIABILITY IN PPWS AND SWS AND (3) PREVENT, REDUCE, AND MANAGE EMERGING HEC. PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE TO: (1) CONDUCT PREPARATORY MEETINGS WITH GOVERNMENT PARTNERS TO OBTAIN SUPPORT FOR COLLARING (2) CONDUCT REFRESHER TRAINING FOR THE ELEPHANT COLLARING TEAM (3) COLLAR A MINIMUM OF TWO INDIVIDUAL ELEPHANTS (3) MONITOR ELEPHANT MOVEMENT USING HOURLY INTERVAL GPS LOGGING DATA

title.narrative: DRIVING PRIORITY CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR ASIAN ELEPHANTS IN THE EASTERN PLAINS LANDSCAPE OF CAMBODIA

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to improve the knowledge base and capacity of authorities and communities to track elephant movements and population trends and reduce human-elephant conflict (HEC) in the Eastern Plains Landscape (EPL) of Cambodia. Phnom Prich Wildlife Sanctuary (PPWS) and Srepok Wildlife Sanctuary (SWS), two adjacent protected areas inside the EPL, are contiguous with Yok Don National Park (YDNP) in Viet Nam and home to 500 Asian elephants. This work aims to reduce threats to wild elephants through advocacy actions based on improved knowledge of elephant population size, movements, and HEC and use results to form the basis for data-driven conservation measures that directly target the most critical threats to the most viable transboundary Asian elephant population in Cambodia and Viet Nam. Project objectives are to: (1) conduct elephant collaring in EPL; (2) conduct fecal DNA assessments to measure elephant population size and viability in PPWS and SWS; and (3) prevent, reduce, and manage emerging HEC. Project activities are to: (1) conduct preparatory meetings with government partners to obtain support for collaring; (2) conduct refresher training for the elephant collaring team; (3) collar a minimum of two individual elephants; (3) monitor elephant movement using hourly interval GPS logging data; (4) conduct preparatory meetings and refresher training with research partners and community-based elephant research team on fecal DNA assessments; (5) collect fecal DNA samples; (6) establish an HEC reporting mechanism for EPL; (7) compile existing data on HEC to establish a baseline on which to inform and measure the effectiveness of interventions; and (8) conduct pilot research and feasibility testing on HEC management measures.

title.narrative: DIRECT PROTECTION TO ASIA S LAST INTACT ELEPHANT CORRIDOR.

description.narrative: In partnership with the Ministry of Environment, the Cardamom Rainforest Protection Program (CRPP) provides direct forest protection to the Southwest Elephant Corridor, Southern Cardamom National Park, Cambodia. The goals of the CRPP are to: (1) protect wild Asian elephants from snaring and prevent poaching of elephants; and (2) conserve elephant habitat and preserve continuous forest cover for elephant movement by preventing encroachment and fragmentation. This project will: (1) support four six-person ranger teams based at the Stung Proat and Chhay Areng ranger stations by funding salaries, training, equipment (such as field boots, backpacks, hammocks, and uniforms), operations, and transportation costs of each station whose rangers will conduct 47,600 km of daily forest and river patrols; (2) strengthen good governance by building strong cases, following-up with the courts on active cases, and providing legal support to the Ministry of Environment rangers responsible for law enforcement; (3) regularly liaise and provide technical guidance to central and provincial government officials regarding development and deforestation activities in the protected area; and (4) use community outreach to strengthen linkages between local communities and the ranger stations to address encroachment and provide rapid response to incidents of human-elephant conflict.

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING CONSERVATION OF THE ENDANGERED PILEATED GIBBON (HYLOBATES PILEATUS) IN PREY LANG WILDLIFE SANCTUARY, CAMBODIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to improve the conservation status of endangered pileated gibbons and their habitats in Prey Lang Wildlife Sanctuary (PLWS) through targeted monitoring and by engaging local stakeholders, primarily indigenous Kuy people, in their protection. Project objectives are (1) A monitoring program is established for assessing trends in population abundance and distribution of pileated gibbons in PLWS; and (2) Reduced threats to gibbons and their habitats through effective co.management with local communities and protected area rang

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING LOCAL CAPACITY FOR GIBBON CONSERVATION IN CAMBODIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to (1) strengthen capacities of local teachers and community members to deliver environmental education in rural communities in gibbon habitat to reduce consumer demand for gibbons as illegal pets and the risk of human-ape conflicts; (2) strengthen the capacity of the Chi Phat Community Anti-Poaching Unit (CAPU) to enforce in-situ protection of critical pileated gibbon habitat in the Cardamom Mountains. This enhanced capacity includes providing patrol teams with necessary field gear, support to pick up snares across nearly 9,000km over the three years, help CAPU coordinate their patrol efforts with Forest Ranger Teams, implement an improved CAPU patrol management system, including a new excel database for tracking and analyzing patrol results, and train CAPU leaders to use the new excel database to manage patrol data; and (3) conduct applied research through monitoring and management of the reintroduced pileated gibbon population in Angkor Archeological Park to support the growing population and address any human-ape conflicts that arise.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SOUTHERN RIVER TERRAPIN, BATUGUR AFFINIS EDWARDMOLLI, IN SOUTHERN CAMBODIA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS THREATS FROM ILLEGAL FISHING, COLLECTION FOR THE ILLEGAL PET TRADE, AND SAND MINING, AMONG OTHERS, TO ONE OF THE FEW REMAINING WILD POPULATIONS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) RECRUITING AND COMPENSATING COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO ASSIST WITH IN-SITU NEST SURVEILLANCE (2) RELEASING ABOUT 50 HEAD-STARTED TURTLES WITH AN INVITATION TO THE ROYAL FAMILY AND A WELL-KNOWN BUDDHIST MONK TO PARTICIPATE IN THE PUBLIC RELEASE BLESSING TO MAXIMIZE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND SUPPORT (3) DEPLOYING SONIC TRANSMITTERS AND RECEIVERS TO TRACK DISPERSAL, HABITAT USE AND SURVIVAL OF RELEASED TURTLES TO INFORM CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND (4) CONDUCTING AN AWARENESS PROGRAM FOCUSED ON SIX KEY VILLAGES CLOSE TO IMPORTANT NESTING BEACHES TO INCREASE COMMUNITY SUPPORT.
